close_symbols: struct MHD_Connection.rq (definition of the request-substructure and its fields: have_chunked_upload, http_mthd, http_ver, some_payload_processed, current_chunk_offset, current_chunk_size)
member: MHD_Connection::(read_buffer capacity/size field) (e.g. read_buffer_size or equivalent)
enum/defines: MHD_ProcRecvDataStage values (MHD_PROC_RECV_INIT, METHOD, URI, HTTPVER, HEADERS, BODY_NORMAL, BODY_CHUNKED, FOOTERS, COOKIE)

enum/defines: MHD_CONNECTION_* state values used (MHD_CONNECTION_FULL_REQ_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_INIT, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_HEADERS_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_FOOTERS_RECEIVING)
prototype + implementation: connection_close_error(struct MHD_Connection *, const char * /* or appropriate signature */)
prototype + implementation: transmit_error_response_static (and/or transmit_error_response_len) and its use of buffer/string functions
prototype + implementation: handle_req_headers_no_space(struct MHD_Connection *, const char *buf, size_t buf_offset)
prototype + implementation: handle_req_chunk_size_line_no_space(struct MHD_Connection *, const char *buf, size_t buf_offset)
prototype + implementation: handle_req_footers_no_space(struct MHD_Connection *, const char *buf, size_t buf_offset)
explanation: For a MISRA C analysis focused on preventing out-of-bounds accesses by functions from <string.h>, we must know exactly what buffers and sizes are passed to any string/memory routines and how callees manipulate them. The target function itself passes c->read_buffer and c->read_buffer_offset (and sometimes NULL/0) into other routines — therefore you need the precise declarations and the buffer capacity information inside struct MHD_Connection to check that any read/write or string functions will be within bounds. The request-substructure (c->rq) fields determine control flow (chunked vs normal body, offsets and sizes) so you must see their types and semantics to reason about comparisons and branches that lead to calls that may touch buffers. All enumerator and state definitions used in assertions and switches are required to understand which branches are reachable and thus which callees and buffer usages must be inspected. The callee functions (connection_close_error, transmit_error_response_static/len, handle_req_headers_no_space, handle_req_chunk_size_line_no_space, handle_req_footers_no_space, has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer) must be inspected (their prototypes and implementations) because they are the places where any <string.h> functions could be invoked on the buffers passed from handle_recv_no_space; you must verify they validate offsets/lengths and do not invoke memcpy/strcpy/strlen/etc. with pointers/sizes that could exceed the buffer capacity. Finally, the error-string macros are included because they are passed into transmit/close helpers and might be copied into responses (potential callers of string functions); knowing whether those are static constant strings or constructed at runtime affects whether additional bounds checks are necessary. Including MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ and daemon type lets you confirm that the assert/branch that leads to the error-handling path is indeed reachable in the daemon configuration (so you know whether the corresponding code paths must be analyzed).
